section.title: Solving Congruences

ul.li: Determine if an integer has a multiplicative inverse, and find it if it exists.
Solve linear congruences by using properties of congruence and/or finding the multiplicative inverse.

section.p: When we are asked to solve for x in an equation like 2x^2 + 4 = 36, we know that we need to look for all values of x that satisfy that equation (x = \pm 4). What if we are asked to solve for x given a congruence?

statement.p: Solve for x in the congruence 2x \equiv 4 \Mod{9}.
Before looking at the solution, try it yourself first! What value(s) of x will satisfy the congruence?

solution.p: We need to find all values of x so that 9 \mid (2x - 4), or 9 \mid 2(x-2).
Since \gcd(2,9) = 1, by we have 9 \mid (x-2), which means x \equiv 2 \Mod{9}.
Note that this is no different from applying directly: since \gcd(2,9) = 1, we can safely divide both sides by 2 to obtain x \equiv 2 \Mod{9}.
This means that the congruence class [2] is the solution to 2x \equiv 4 \Mod{9}, or that all integers in \{\ldots,-16,-7,2,11,\ldots\} satisfy the congruence.

section.p: The final answer in the above example is typical of solutions to congruences: since we are working modulo n, answers will be congruence classes from \{[0],[1],\ldots,[n-1]\}. Hence when asked to solve for x given a congruence, you should express your answer as a congruence class ([2]), or as a statement of congruence like x \equiv 2 \Mod{9}, which makes the modulus explicit.

statement.p: Solve the congruence 2x \equiv 6 \Mod{10}, and express your answer using congruence classes of the original modulus.

solution.p: We can apply here to divide through by 2, and we get x \equiv 3 \Mod{5}. Modulo 10, this is the same as x \equiv 3 \Mod{10} \text{ and } x \equiv 8 \Mod{10}. So the original congruence has two solutions in \{[0],[1],\ldots,[9]\}, namely [3] and [8].

hint.p: There are only 7 congruence classes to check, since we are working modulo 7.

section.p: We've seen that dividing both sides by a constant is not always possible. Recall instead that in the real numbers, division by a nonzero number x is the same as multiplication by its reciprocal \frac{1}{x}. The number \frac{1}{x} is sometimes called the inverse of x since they cancel each other out when multplied together.
We define a similar concept for modular arithmetic.

statement.p: Given natural numbers a, m such that \gcd(a,m) = 1, the number b is called a multiplicative inverse of a modulo m if ab \equiv 1 \Mod{m}.
We can denote this inverse as a^{-1} = b, or by a^{-1} \Mod{m} to make the modulus explicit.

section.p: In we are really saying that any number in [b] is a multiplicative inverse of a modulo m, though we will usually be interested in finding that specific inverse that is also in the set \{0,1,\ldots,m-1\}. This can now be used when solving congruences of the form ax \equiv b \Mod{n} where a \nmid b. Instead of dividing both sides by a (which can't always be done), we multiply both sides by the inverse of a.

Given a, m \in \mathbb{N} such that \gcd(a,m) = 1, prove that the multiplicative inverse of a modulo m is unique (up to congruence class).

hint.p: Assume that c and d are both multiplicative inverses of a modulo m. Show that c \equiv d \Mod{m}.

statement.p: Use the previous exercise to argue that ax \equiv b \Mod{m} has a unique solution (up to congruence class) if \gcd(a,m) = 1.
Does the converse hold? That is, if we know that ax \equiv b \Mod{m} has a unique solution, can we conclude that \gcd(a,m) = 1?

Since \gcd(6,16) \gt 1, the number 6 has no multiplicative inverse modulo 16. Solve the congruences 6x \equiv 3 \Mod{16} and 6x \equiv 4 \Mod{16}. How many solutions do you get for each one (modulo 16)?
